data.text: How to Deal with Loneliness when Bikepacking
I'm new to bikepacking and I'm planning my first short solo trip. How to people deal with being with themselves? Being alone is exciting but also a little unnerving
Kindle and earplugs 🙂
data.author: Jase Hoad

data.text: On a recent solo tour, I didn't book accommodation or trains, ferries etc more than a day in advance. Thus, I could bail fairly cheaply. Took a few days of procrastination before I bit the bullet but it was fantastic.
data.author: Jeff Humm

data.text: I love the freedom of being on my own. However, some of my best trips have involved chatting and getting to know people. You’re never totally on your own. People just love to inquire about the bike and bags..it’s kinda weird.
data.author: Paul Tozer

data.text: No problem..
data.author: Tomaž Švagan

data.text: Never had a problem; I enjoy the time by myself and find that you get more social when I stop at cafes etc. Also - get yourself a mascot for company 😀
data.author: Joseph Alan Robertson

data.text: Boris always comes along with me too.. 😎.. He loves wild camping

data.text: love this idea. Also, what TT bars are those. They look pretty compact?
data.author: Andrew Hadfield-Ames

data.text: they are Prime Noosa aero bars. Advice - make sure you get the ‘riser’ kit also because it really helps to have them about an inch off of the bars (both for comfort and to provide room for your bar bags and food pouches). Also Prime do an out-front mount that holds your Garmin. The whole set up is really comfortable 👍🏻
data.author: Joseph Alan Robertson

data.text: Enjoy it.
data.author: Robert Brown

data.text: Take a Book, have a video you like to watch on your phone, I always wild camp, in fact I'm traveling across europe on me tod, u try buy english written book in europe 😂 tbh : I cannot be around noisy places, birdsong, trains & babbling brooks to camp next to, for me isda bizz, wild camp six days out of seven....
data.author: Larry Gowar

data.text: It's a leap of faith. You just have to give it a go . If you feel uneasy try a campsite first . Gradually build up confidence . I suppose being nervous is part of it . It's the not being 100% sure of your route , or when you'll eat or when/where you're going to sleep are ( for me ) the reasons I love it ! Give it a go ! 🚴🏻‍♀️🏴󠁧󠁢󠁳󠁣󠁴󠁿
data.author: Peter Couttie

data.text: eventually I brought a Garmin Explore, shows me trails I would never come across...
data.author: Larry Gowar

data.text: Hip flask helps 🥃👍
data.author: Andy Wright

data.text: Listen to music, look at the scenery. At camp, bum around on my phone if there are no jobs to do. But I also live alone so fairly used to it
data.author: Henk Kommers

data.text: I've just done my first solo trip and like you I was excited but also anxious but I absolutely loved it.
data.author: Paul Lowdon

data.text: I always tour on my own; that's the best part. Besides, you get to bump into some truly remarkable people along the way. The further out, the more interesting the strangers.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: Sometimes there will be other people around and conversation is far more likely if you are a solo traveller. There is usually something interesting to hear or learn. At other times it is nice to have time for quiet contemplation of the natural world around you. I also take an iPad loaded with books, generally novels set in the region or country that I’m travelling through. It makes both the book and the country more understandable. It’s never boring.
data.author: Steve Carden

data.text: "I've got this". And a mobile phone. 👍 Seriously, you've got this💪
data.author: Simon Walford

data.text: Talk to random people. That's part of the adventure for me.
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: Travelling alone opens you up to meeting far more people and experiences. Travelling in two’s or more stops some people talking with you. Being alone exposes you to both great experiences and perhaps a slight increase risk of negative things .,., but out there there is loads more good than bad …. So go for it!
data.author: Richard Howley

data.text: I'm a soloist, but my panniers sometimes inspire questions from interested people when I'm stopped at cafes etc..... If I'm in the mood I'll chat for an hour if not then just the pleasantries and off I go... I suppose what I mean is you can be isolated if you like but it's quite easy to get back into the open..... On the road anything goes 🤘
data.author: Mark Randlesome

data.text: Are you never alone at home
data.author: Mark Connelly

data.text: I've travelled the world working solo, cycled everywhere solo. Nothing beats it. Complete freedom without being reliant. I talk to anyone and find your never alone. The whole world is one family. You tap into and out of company as you go meeting folk. Stay positive and erase any demons. There's always angels good people out there to help in case you need it. Best of luck. If your up Lancashire way I'll join you for part of your ride.
data.author: Naz Whicker

data.text: hi Naz, I'm cycling up to The lake District in the middle of July. It will be my first tour, I'm excited and nervous at the same time. I'm planning to wild camp for the two weeks of my ride. I liked what you wrote above so thank you for that. Take care buddy, from Mirfield, nr.huddersfied.
data.author: Jeremy Brown

data.text: Well the offers open to you also my friend. Coming through Blackburn or thereabouts let me know. I'll join you for part of the way. Did Blackburn to Blackpool yesterday. Next week going to Lichfield over couple days myself to see the cathedral there. Overnight in Stoke.
data.author: Naz Whicker

data.text: I talk to the voices in my head
data.author: Doo Little

data.text: I love the solitude of solo. As already said it's also easy to strike up random conversations on your own. Just go for it and I'm sure you'll get on just fine. ❤️
data.author: Andrew Goodberry

data.text: Thanks for this post. I'm going solo Friday to do the WKW Cornwall. I've been seriously up and down about doing it but decided if I didn't I'd regret it forever, and its only 4 days out on my own. See what gives. Here goes! 😬
data.author: Andrew Clark

data.text: enjoy your cycling tour Andrew, I guess 4 days is a good start. I'm going in July for my first time and I'm planning 2 weeks, think I might just cut it to 1 week. I've a question for you,how you going to be charging your phone and other stuff? Take care Andrew and looking forward to hear about your journey.
data.author: Jeremy Brown

data.text: I've got a dynamo front hub which will charge my phone at about 10% per hour. Also have Ankor battery pack but I'm sure some campsites will charge stuff for a meagre fee
data.author: Andrew Clark

data.text: Maybe do short ride to start with
data.author: Andrew Clark

data.text: Don’t worry about the axe murders…..🤣 seriously if you’re worried to a campsite overnight, but if wild camping the old mantra of arrive late, leave early should hold you in good stead. Obviously at this time of year the nights are short.
data.author: Robert Iredale

data.text: I love the freedom of travelling alone. I stop when I want, I eat when I want, I stay in bed when I want, I visit the places I want! I don't feel alone, the landscape, wildlife, trees and flowers are companions. When I meet people on the journey, conversation and human contact are cherished, however briefly.
data.author: Laurie Piper

data.text: Your never really alone, I chat to anyone, and take a good radio with you it's nice to listen to at night.
data.author: Ian Mort

data.text: Being by yourself is great. You can do whatever you want to do.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: All of the above. You are FAR more likely to talk to other people if you are on your own and people are FAR more likely to approach you to chat
